newsitem.title: ROMANIA: BUCHAREST BOURSE TO GET THREE MORE STOCKS.
newsitem.headline: BUCHAREST BOURSE TO GET THREE MORE STOCKS.

text.p: Three Romanian companies will join the Bucharest bourse this week, bringing to 32 the total number of traded stocks, the exchange said on Tuesday.
It said the newcomers were pharmaceutical maker Antibiotice SA, oil drilling company Foraj Sonde Ploiesti SA and hotelier Turism Transilvania SA.
The shares of Antibiotice will be traded on Bourse first tier, while other two shares will start to be traded on second-tier.

Antibiotice is a state-run company with a capital of 65.9 billion lei divided in shares with a nominal value of 1,000 lei each. The pharmaceutical maker was privatised under a mass selloff launched in 1995, whith 49 percent of its equity subscribed in exchange for coupons. The State Ownership Fund (FPS) has 51 percent.
Foraj Sonde SA Ploiesti has a share capital of 9.8 billion lei, or 392,176 shares with a nominal value of 25,000 lei each.
It was also privatised under the selloff, with 53 percent acquired for coupons, while the remaining 47 percent remained in the FPS portofolio, a stock exchange statement said.
The third company to join the bourse, state-run hotelier Turism Transilvania SA, has an equity capital of 34.67 billion lei in shares with a face value of 25,000 lei.
The FPS holds 70 percent from its capital, the Private Ownership Fund had 8.9 percent while other investors had 21.1 percent.
Traders said new listings were a good sign for the market's liquidity.
"I expect the newcomers on the bourse and I think the investors will be interesed to see other shares in trading which will boost the volumes and liquidity of the market", one broker said.
He adeed that new listings in Romania's pharmaceutical or chemical idustry would atract more foreign investors on local capital market.

The bourse has only three first-tier listings -- Azomures SA fertiliser maker, which has dominated the bourse since it opened late in 1995, and chemical plant Oltchim SA and pharmaceutical maker Terapia SA , both of which joined the market earlier this year.
Twenty-six companies are currently traded on the second tier. REUTER
